body.p:
Rev. S. Morais
Rev & Dear Sir

Your welcome favor of the 15th is duly
at hand. Though there is a mass of miscellaneous work
on my desk I give an answer to your's the preference. Per,
mit me to thank you for your kind sentiments. I fer,
vently second the good wishes you are kind enough to
express concerning my boy. He is growing nicely and pro
mises to be a sturdy, healthy, little fellow. I must also
thank you for your encouraging remarks. I have always
endeavored to merit your good opinion—of great value
to me, and shall continue to do so. Whatever Providence
may have in store for me I shall accept as my mission
in life. For the present my course lies through the
wilds of Texas and Louisiana. The South—spite all
that apologists may say to the contrary—is an [Hebrew]
[Hebrew]. Religion is largely at a discount, and I
feel that i am wanted here. Thus far I have done
my duty, though my path is beset with difficulties.
I shall struggle; and if my labors will be crowned

with that degree of success that hitherto has attended
them I shall have every reason to thank God and be
satisfied. My labors are for the present, my studies for
the future.

My health, for the present, is quite good again, though
there is no telling when the fever may return. I am stri
ving to keep it away permanently by occasional doses
of quinine, plenty of exercise at the dawn of day
and a subsequent cold water bath. Between the hours
of nine and six it is impossible to be in the streets.
It is almost [Hebrew]. With the thermomether
99° in the shade, we have neither rest nor comfort, until
at nights the cool breezes from the Gulf reinvigorate
exhausted nature.

Concerning the [Hebrew] you speak of, you will
permit me to say a few words. It has been a source
of annoyance to me, that my name has been connected
with an affair for which I was not in the least
responsible. I am candid enough to confess to you
my friend and adviser—that my letter to the Ame
rican Israelite was written under the influence of the
malicious blow, but at my congregation by an ano,

nymous correspondent in the same paper. Its author
is a lesser-social and religious--[Hebrew]
[Hebrew]. A low-life, without principle, name or character,
an Ishmaelite, [Hebrew]. The man is a quasi
orthodox, but observes nothing. His orthodoxy consists solely
as reviling my congregation in particular and "reform" in ge
neral. He is an ignorant, vulgar tradesman why must he
constitute himself censor? He should have kept his peace
and leave stricture-making to such as are fit and
able. You will object that such as he are not worthy
of notice, no matter what they say; at this time I grant
that objection but at the time when I saw my congre
gation reviled in the American Israelite and knowing
well what a precious morsel of gossip it would be
for the would-be Jewish papers my blood, "rose
within me" and I wrote that annihilating letter.
I am sincerely sorry for some of its phrases
but the man deserved it—and more. As to the
fact "of what happened—at a late festivity"
I was ignorant of the very fact of there being
a supper until I came to the ball room. When

I noticed the disregard of Kashrut I was sparing
in neither strictures nor demonstrations. But cui bono?
It was an affair with which neither the congregation
nor its minister were concerned. The publicity given
to the matter by the Jewish Record and its unfavorable
comment upon the same as well as its "slap" at
myself are the result of Mr. Jones' unwarrantable
hatred towards myself. Of this I will not speak
now. I have not noticed the attack nor will I do
so but [Hebrew]. Believe me, dear sir, that I
have deplored the occurrence. But I was not to be
silent and see a low-life make statements, devoid
of truth. It was more the man, to whom I objected
than his statements. The latter would have received a
different reply had they come from a different
source. And now, let us leave this matter rest. I
trust that my explanation has satisfied you. Time
is beginning to be very valuable to me now and though
reluctantly, I close with my heartfelt wishes for
your long life and happiness. In my next permit me
to discuss matters of a different and more inte
resting nature. Please let me hear from you. Sincerely Yours Jacob Voorsanger
